0.text: THERESA MAY: I have just chaired a meeting of Cabinet where we agreed that the Government

5.text:
should call a general election to be held
on 8 June. I want to explain the reasons for

13.text: that decision, what will happen next and the choice facing the British people when you

19.text: come to vote in this election. Last summer after the country voted to leave the EU, Britain

29.text: needed certainty, stability and strong leadership and since I became Prime Minister the Government

37.text: has delivered precisely that. Despite predictions of immediate financial and economic danger

45.text: since the referendum we have seen consumer confidence remain high, record numbers of

51.text: jobs and economic growth that ass has exceeded all expectations.

57.text: We have also delivered on the mandate we were handed by the referendum result. Britain is

64.text: leaving the EU and there can be no turning back. And as we look to the future the Government

73.text:
has the right plan for negotiating our new
relationship with Europe. We want a deep and

80.text: special partnership between a strong and successful EU and a UK that is free to chart its own

89.text: way in the world. That means we will regain control of our own money, our own laws and

96.text: our own borders and we will be free to strike trade deals with old friends and new partners all around the world.

106.text:
This is the right approach and it is in the
national interest, but the other political

113.text: parties oppose it. At this moment of enormous national significance there should be unity

121.text:
here in Westminster, but instead there is
division. The country is coming together but

128.text: Westminster is not. In recent weeks Labour have threatened to vote against the final

135.text: agreement we reach with the EU, the Liberal Democrats have said they want to grind the

142.text: business of government to a standstill, the SNP say they will vote against the legislation

149.text: that formally repeals Britain's membership of the EU and unelected members of the House

155.text: of Lords have vowed to fight us every step of the way. Our opponents believe because

162.text:
the Government's majority is so small that
our resolve will weaken and that they can

170.text: They are wrong, they underestimate our determination to get the job done and I am not prepared

179.text: to let them endanger the security of millions of working people across the country because

185.text: what they are doing jeopardises the work we must do to prepare for Brexit at home and

192.text: it weakens the Government's negotiating position in Europe. If we do not hold a General Election

199.text: now their political game playing will continue and the negotiations with the EU will reach

207.text:
their most difficult stage in the run-up to
the next scheduled election. Division in Westminster

214.text:
will risk our ability to make a success of
Brexit and it will cause damaging uncertainty

223.text: So we need a general election and we need one now because we have at this moment a one-off

230.text: chance to get this done while the EU agrees its negotiating position and before the detailed

237.text: talks begin. I have only recently and reluctantly come this conclusion. since I became Prime Minister

247.text:
I have said there should be no election
until 2020 but now I have concluded that the

253.text: only way to guarantee certainty and stability for the years ahead is to hold this election

260.text:
and seek your support for the decisions I
must take.

264.text: And so tomorrow I will move a motion in the House of Commons calling for a general election

270.text:
to be held on 8 June. That motion, as set
out by the Fixed Term Parliament Act, will

277.text:
require a two thirds majority of the House
of Commons. So I have a simple challenge to

282.text:
the opposition parties. You have criticised
the Government's vision for Brexit, you have

287.text: challenged our objectives, you have threatened to block the legislation we put before Parliament.

294.text: This is your moment to show you mean it, to show you are not opposing the Government for

299.text: the sake of it, to show that you do not treat politics as a game.

305.text:
Let us tomorrow vote for an election, let
us put forward our plans for Brexit and our

310.text: alternative programmes for government and then let the people decide. And the decision

318.text: facing the country will be all about leadership. It will be a choice between strong and stable

325.text:
leadership in the national interest, with
me as your Prime Minister, or weak and unstable

331.text: coalition government led by Jeremy Corbyn, propped up by the Liberal Democrats, who want

337.text: to re-open the divisions of the referendum, and Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP.

343.text: Every vote for the Conservatives will make it harder for opposition politicians who want

348.text: to stop me from getting the job done. Every vote for the Conservatives will make me stronger

355.text:
when I negotiate for Britain with the Prime
Ministers, Presidents and Chancellors of the EU.

361.text:
Every vote for the Conservatives will
mean we can stick to our plan for a stronger

366.text: Britain and take the right long-term decisions for a more secure future.

373.text:
It was with reluctance that I decided the
country needs this election but it is with

378.text:
strong conviction that I say it is necessary
to secure the strong and stable leadership

384.text: the country needs to see us through Brexit and beyond. So tomorrow, let the House of

391.text: Commons vote for an early election, let everybody put forward their proposals for Brexit and

397.text: their programme for government and let us remove the risk of uncertainty and instability

404.text: and continue to give the country the strong and stable leadership it demands.
